Claude Sonnet 4.6: Murder by a group of 5+ on grounds of race, caste, or personal belief (Mob Lynching)	Section 103(2) – Punishment is death or life imprisonment with fine; a landmark new specific provision.
Snatching (new offence for chain/bag snatching)	Section 304 – Punishable with imprisonment up to 3 years and fine.
Organised Crime (first time in general penal law)	Section 111 – Covers organised criminal syndicates; punishable with rigorous imprisonment of 5 years to life, or death.
Terrorist Act (incorporated into general penal law)	Section 113 – Punishable with rigorous imprisonment of life or death in fatal cases.
Sexual intercourse by deceitful means / false promise of marriage	Section 69 – Punishable with imprisonment up to 10 years and fine.
Death by rash driving + fleeing the scene without reporting	Section 106(2) – Enhanced punishment of up to 10 years and fine; a new specific sub-section.
Unnatural Offences (IPC Section 377 equivalent)	Not retained in BNS – Consensual same-sex acts were decriminalised by the Supreme Court (Navtej Singh Johar, 2018); BNS omits this provision entirely.
Receiving / Concealing Stolen Property (consolidated)	Section 317 – All related provisions consolidated here; punishable with imprisonment up to 3 years and/or fine.
General Attempt to Commit Suicide by a distressed person	Effectively decriminalised – BNS omits the IPC Section 309 equivalent for ordinary citizens, aligning with the Mental Healthcare Act, 2017.
Attempt to commit suicide to compel/restrain a public servant	Section 226 – Punishable with simple imprisonment up to 1 year and/or fine.
Criminal Conspiracy	Section 61 – Punishment varies with the gravity of the conspired offence.
Adultery	Not present in BNS – Omitted entirely, as IPC Section 497 was struck down by the Supreme Court in Joseph Shine v. Union of India (2018).
General Exception: Act of a person of Unsound Mind	Section 22 – Mirrors the old IPC Section 84; act is not an offence if done in a state of unsoundness of mind.
Right of Private Defence extending to causing Death	Section 37 – Specifies seven circumstances where the right extends to voluntarily causing death.
Acts endangering Sovereignty, Unity & Integrity of India (replaced Sedition)	Section 152 – Broader and stricter than old Section 124A IPC; punishable with life imprisonment or up to 7 years and fine.
Criminal Intimidation	Section 351 – Punishable with imprisonment up to 2 years and/or fine; aggravated forms carry higher penalties.
House-trespass to commit an offence	Section 331 – Punishment depends on the nature of the offence intended; sub-sections prescribe varying terms.
Petty Organised Crime (vehicle theft, pickpocketing by a gang)	Section 112 – Punishable with imprisonment of 1 to 7 years and fine; a new and distinct provision.
Public Nuisance (definition)	Section 292 – Defines acts that cause common injury, danger, or annoyance to the public.
Gang Rape of a woman under 18 years of age	Section 70(2) – Punishable with rigorous imprisonment for the remainder of natural life or death.

Claude Sonnet 4.6: General Attempt to Commit an Offence punishable with imprisonment	Section 62 – Whoever attempts to commit an offence and fails is punishable with imprisonment up to half the longest term provided for that offence.

Joint Liability – Common Intention (act by several persons)	Section 3(5) – When a criminal act is done by several persons in furtherance of a common intention, each is liable as if it were done by them alone.
General Exception: Child Under Seven Years of Age	Section 20 – Nothing is an offence done by a child under 7 years of age; absolute immunity from criminal liability.
General Exception: Act Done by Accident or Misfortune	Section 24 – Nothing is an offence done by accident or misfortune while performing a lawful act in a lawful manner with due care.
Right of Private Defence (primary declaration)	Section 34 – Declares that nothing is an offence done in the exercise of the right of private defence of body or property.
Abetment of a Thing (definition)	Section 45 – Defines abetment as instigation, conspiracy, or intentional aiding to commit an act.
Waging War Against the Government of India	Section 147 – Punishable with death or life imprisonment, and fine; the gravest offence against the State.
Promoting Enmity Between Different Groups (religion, race, language, etc.)	Section 196 – Punishable with imprisonment up to 3 years and/or fine; 5 years if committed at a place of worship.
Deliberate & Malicious Acts Outraging Religious Feelings	Section 299 – Punishable with imprisonment up to 3 years and/or fine.
False Charge of an Offence with Intent to Injure	Section 250 – Punishable with imprisonment up to 7 years and fine, mirroring the gravity of the falsely charged offence.
Harbouring or Concealing an Offender to screen from legal punishment	Section 238 – Punishable with imprisonment varying with the gravity of the offence committed by the person harboured.
Voluntarily Causing a Woman with Child to Miscarry (Abortion)	Section 88 – Punishable with imprisonment up to 3 years and/or fine; up to 7 years if the woman is quick with child.
Kidnapping or Maiming a Minor for Begging	Section 141 – Punishable with rigorous imprisonment up to 10 years and fine; a child-protective provision.
Trafficking of Persons (definition and punishment)	Section 143 – Punishable with rigorous imprisonment of 7 to 10 years and fine; aggravated forms attract life imprisonment.
Unlawfully Compelling a Person to Labour Against Their Will	Section 144 – Punishable with imprisonment up to 1 year and/or fine, or both.
Habitually Dealing in Slaves	Section 142 – Punishable with imprisonment for life or rigorous imprisonment up to 10 years, and fine.
Mischief by Killing or Maiming an Animal	Section 325 – Punishable with imprisonment up to 5 years and/or fine for killing/maiming animals of prescribed value.
Deceitfully Inducing Belief of Lawful Marriage for Cohabitation	Section 84 – Punishable with imprisonment up to 10 years and fine; protects against fraudulent cohabitation.
Being a Thug (historical offence retained under BNS)	Section 310 – Whoever is a thug shall be punished with imprisonment for life and fine; retained from the original IPC equivalent.
Making/Publishing False Statements or Rumours Conducing to Public Mischief	Section 197 – Punishable with imprisonment up to 3 years and/or fine; up to 7 years during war or national emergency.

Kruti: Section 62 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS) is the general section for attempting to commit an offence punishable with imprisonment. This section prescribes punishment for attempts to commit offences that carry imprisonment, whether for life or otherwise. [1]

Section 3(5) of the BNS establishes joint liability when a criminal act is done by several persons in furtherance of a common intention. This is the BNS equivalent of the former Section 34 of the IPC. [2]

Section 20 of the BNS states that nothing is an offence which is done by a child under seven years of age. This is based on the legal doctrine of "Doli Incapax," meaning the child is incapable of forming criminal intent. [3]

Section 18 of the BNS provides the general exception for an act done by accident or misfortune while doing a lawful act. This section states that such acts are not considered offences if done without criminal intent or knowledge. [4]

Section 34 of the BNS is the primary section that declares nothing is an offence which is done in the exercise of the right of private defence. This section outlines the conditions under which a person can defend themselves or their property. [4]
Section 45 of the BNS defines 'Abetment of a thing'. This section outlines the three forms of abetment: instigation, conspiracy, and intentional aid. [6]
Section 147 of the BNS penalizes waging or attempting to wage war against the Government of India. This is the BNS equivalent of the former Section 121 of the IPC. [7]
Section 196 of the BNS penalizes promoting enmity between different groups on grounds of religion, race, or language. This section aims to prevent communal disharmony and hate speech. [8]
Section 299 of the BNS criminalizes deliberate and malicious acts intended to outrage the religious feelings of any class. This section penalizes insults to religion or religious beliefs. [9]
Section 248 of the BNS applies if someone falsely charges a person with an offence with the intent to injure them. This section penalizes false criminal proceedings. [10]
Section 249 of the BNS penalizes harbouring or concealing an offender to screen them from legal punishment. This section outlines different punishments based on the severity of the offence. [11]
Section 86 of the BNS prescribes the punishment for voluntarily causing a woman with child to miscarry. This section addresses the offence of causing miscarriage. [1]
Section 137 of the BNS criminalizes kidnapping or maiming a minor for the purposes of begging. This section addresses the exploitation of minors. [1]
Section 141 of the BNS defines and punishes the offence of 'Trafficking of Person'. This section addresses the illegal trade of persons. [1]
Section 144 of the BNS penalizes unlawful compulsory labour, also known as Forced Labour. This section addresses the exploitation of individuals through coercion. [1]
Section 122 of the BNS penalizes mischief by killing or maiming an animal. This section addresses harm to animals. [1]
Section 80 of the BNS addresses the offence of a man deceitfully inducing a belief of lawful marriage to cause cohabitation. This section penalizes fraudulent marriages. [1]
Section 156 of the BNS penalizes being a 'Thug'. This section is the exact equivalent of the former Section 342 of the IPC. [1]

Section 152 of the BNS penalizes making or publishing statements, false information, or rumours conducing to public mischief. This section addresses the spread of false information that causes public disturbance. [1]
